markdown.markdown:
```{python}
#| label: setup
#| include: false
import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
```


```{python}
import pandas as pd
import wbgapi as wb
```

```{python}
# Define the indicators to download
indicators = {
    'gdp_per_capita': 'NY.GDP.PCAP.CD',
    'gdp_growth_rate': 'NY.GDP.MKTP.KD.ZG',
    'inflation_rate': 'FP.CPI.TOTL.ZG',
    'unemployment_rate': 'SL.UEM.TOTL.ZS',
    'total_population': 'SP.POP.TOTL',
    'life_expectancy': 'SP.DYN.LE00.IN',
    'adult_literacy_rate': 'SE.ADT.LITR.ZS',
    'income_inequality': 'SI.POV.GINI',
    'health_expenditure_gdp_share': 'SH.XPD.CHEX.GD.ZS',
    'measles_immunisation_rate': 'SH.IMM.MEAS',
    'education_expenditure_gdp_share': 'SE.XPD.TOTL.GD.ZS',
    'primary_school_enrolment_rate': 'SE.PRM.ENRR',
    'exports_gdp_share': 'NE.EXP.GNFS.ZS'
}

# Get the list of country codes for the "World" region
country_codes = wb.region.members('WLD')

# Download data for countries only in 2022
df = wb.data.DataFrame(indicators.values(), economy=country_codes, time=2022, skipBlanks=True, labels=True).reset_index()

# Delete the 'economy' column
df = df.drop(columns=['economy'], errors='ignore')

# Create a reversed dictionary mapping indicator codes to names
# Rename the columns and convert all names to lowercase
df.rename(columns=lambda x: {v: k for k, v in indicators.items()}.get(x, x).lower(), inplace=True)

# Sort 'country' in ascending order
df = df.sort_values('country', ascending=True)

# Reset the index after sorting
df = df.reset_index(drop=True)

# Display the number of rows and columns
print(df.shape)

# Display the first few rows of the data
print(df.head(3))

# Save the data to a CSV file
df.to_csv('wdi.csv', index=False)


```

## 3. Exploratory Data Analysis

I will analyze the following three indicators from the dataset: 1. GDP per capita 2. Life expectancy 3. Unemployment rate

### Summary Statistics

1.  GDP per capita shows extremely wide variation, ranging from about \$251 to over \$226,000.

-   The mean (\$21,076) is far higher than the median (\$7,656), indicating a right-skewed distribution. A few wealthy countries drive up the average while most economies have much lower income per person.
-   The large standard deviation (\$30,994) confirms strong inequality in economic output across countries.

2.  Life expectancy values range from 18.8 years to 85.7 years, with a mean of about 73.1 years.

-   The interquartile range (67.8 – 78.5) indicates that most countries cluster around 70–80 years.
-   The relatively small standard deviation (≈ 7.9) shows that life expectancy is less dispersed than income levels, reflecting global improvements in public health.

3.  Unemployment rate varies from 0.13 % to 35.36 %, averaging around 7.2 %.

-   The wide spread and high standard deviation (≈ 5.8) point to diverse labor market conditions — some economies experience full employment while others face severe unemployment.
-   The median (≈ 5.3 %) being below the mean also suggests a right-skewed distribution, with a few countries suffering unusually high unemployment.

```{python}
#| label: summary-stats
#| fig-cap: "Table 1. Summary statistics for GPD/capita, life expectancy, and unemployment rate."

# Show summary statistics for our chosen indicators
df[['gdp_per_capita', 'life_expectancy', 'unemployment_rate']].describe()
```

### Correlation Matrices

The correlation matrix highlights the strength and direction of linear relationships among the three key indicators:

1.  GDP per capita and life expectancy (r = 0.57): This is a moderately strong positive correlation. Countries with higher income/person tend to have longer average lifespans. This makes sense, as higher income levels typically correspond to better access to healthcare, nutrition, and education, all of which improve life expectancy.

2.  GDP per capita and unemployment rate (r = –0.21): The negative correlation suggests that wealthier economies generally experience lower unemployment, although the relationship is pretty weak.

3.  Life expectancy and unemployment rate (r = –0.11): This slight negative relationship implies that higher unemployment may correspond weakly with lower life expectancy, but the association is minimal. The weak coefficient indicates that labor market conditions alone are not a major determinant of life expectancy across countries.

```{python}
#| label: correlations
#| fig-cap: "Table 2. Correlation scores between GDP/capita, life expectancy, and unemployment rate."

# Show correlation matrices
df[['gdp_per_capita', 'life_expectancy', 'unemployment_rate']].corr()
```

### Distributions

GDP per capita is heavily skewed right, showing large wealth inequalities across countries. Unemployment rate is also skewed right, ranging from 0 to 35%. Life expectancy is the closest to being normally distributed with only a few small outliers below 50.

```{python}
#| label: distributions
#| fig-cap: "Figure 1. Top 10 countries by GDP per capita. Source: World Bank WDI (2023)."

import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt


fig, axes = plt.subplots(1, 3, figsize=(15, 4))

sns.histplot(df['gdp_per_capita'], kde=True, ax=axes[0], color='skyblue')
axes[0].set_title('GDP per capita distribution')

sns.histplot(df['life_expectancy'], kde=True, ax=axes[1], color='lightgreen')
axes[1].set_title('Life expectancy distribution')

sns.histplot(df['unemployment_rate'], kde=True, ax=axes[2], color='salmon')
axes[2].set_title('Unemployment rate distribution')

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()
```

## 4. Visualizations

The scatter plot shows an upward relationship between GDP per capita and life expectancy. Wealthier nations tend to have longer lifespans, though the relationship flattens for very high-income countries, suggesting diminishing returns from income on health outcomes.

```{python}
#| label: fig-gdp-life
#| fig-cap: "Figure 2. Relationship between GDP per capita and life expectancy. Source: World Bank WDI (2023)."
#| echo: false

import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

sns.set(style="whitegrid")

plt.figure(figsize=(7,5))
sns.regplot(
    data=df,
    x="gdp_per_capita", 
    y="life_expectancy",
    scatter_kws={"alpha":0.6, "s":40, "color":"skyblue"},
    line_kws={"color":"darkblue", "linewidth":2}
)
plt.title("GDP per Capita vs Life Expectancy")
plt.xlabel("GDP per capita (current US$)")
plt.ylabel("Life expectancy (years)")
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

```

The bar chart highlights the top 10 wealthiest countries by GDP per capita, with clear outliers at the top end. This visual emphasizes global economic inequality, where a few small, high-income economies far exceed the global average income levels.

```{python}
#| label: fig-top10-gdp
#| fig-cap: "Figure 3. Top 10 countries by GDP per capita. Source: World Bank WDI (2023)."
#| echo: false

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

# Filter and rank top 10 countries by GDP per capita
top10 = df[['country', 'gdp_per_capita']].dropna().nlargest(10, 'gdp_per_capita')

plt.figure(figsize=(9,5))
sns.barplot(data=top10, x='gdp_per_capita', y='country', palette='Blues_r')
plt.title("Top 10 Countries by GDP per Capita")
plt.xlabel("GDP per capita (current US$)")
plt.ylabel("Country")
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()


```

## 5. Table Summary

```{python}
#| label: tbl-compare
#| tbl-cap: "Table 3. Comparison of key economic and social indicators: Top 10 GDP per capita countries vs. global averages. Source: World Bank WDI (2023)."
#| echo: false

import pandas as pd

# Select relevant columns
cols = ['country', 'gdp_per_capita', 'life_expectancy', 'unemployment_rate']
subset = df[cols].dropna()

# TOP 10 SUMMARY 
top10 = subset.nlargest(10, 'gdp_per_capita')

top10_summary = {
    'Group': ['Top 10 GDP per capita countries'],
    'Mean GDP per capita (US$)': [top10['gdp_per_capita'].mean()],
    'Mean Life expectancy (years)': [top10['life_expectancy'].mean()],
    'Mean Unemployment rate (%)': [top10['unemployment_rate'].mean()]
}

# GLOBAL SUMMARY 
global_summary = {
    'Group': ['Global average (all countries)'],
    'Mean GDP per capita (US$)': [subset['gdp_per_capita'].mean()],
    'Mean Life expectancy (years)': [subset['life_expectancy'].mean()],
    'Mean Unemployment rate (%)': [subset['unemployment_rate'].mean()]
}

# Combine both summaries
comparison_df = pd.concat([
    pd.DataFrame(top10_summary),
    pd.DataFrame(global_summary)
]).reset_index(drop=True)

# Format and apply color gradients
styled_table = (
    comparison_df.style
    .format({
        'Mean GDP per capita (US$)': '{:,.2f}',
        'Mean Life expectancy (years)': '{:,.2f}',
        'Mean Unemployment rate (%)': '{:,.2f}'
    })
    .background_gradient(
        subset=['Mean GDP per capita (US$)', 'Mean Life expectancy (years)'],
        cmap='Greens'  # higher = greener
    )
    .background_gradient(
        subset=['Mean Unemployment rate (%)'],
        cmap='Reds'   # higher = redder 
    )
    .set_table_styles([
        {'selector': 'th', 'props': [('text-align', 'center'), ('background-color', '#f2f2f2')]},
        {'selector': 'td', 'props': [('text-align', 'center')]}
    ])
    .set_caption("Key indicators for top 10 GDP per capita countries compared to global averages.")
)

styled_table

```

### Discussion

According to global data from the World Bank [@worldbank2023], GDP per capita and life expectancy are strongly correlated, a trend also shown in Our World in Data [@owid_life_vs_gdp]. Our data analysis also supports this finding, as in Figure @fig-gdp-life, there is a clear positive relationship between GDP per capita and life expectancy.

Figure @fig-top10-gdp highlights the top 10 economies by income, while Figure @fig-top10-life shows that countries with the highest life expectancy are also among the most economically advanced.

Finally, Table @tbl-compare summarizes how the top 10 wealthiest countries outperform the global average on key indicators, reinforcing the trends seen across the figures.

```{python}
#| label: tbl-compare
#| tbl-cap: "Table 3. Comparison of key economic and social indicators: Top 10 GDP per capita countries vs. global averages. Source: World Bank WDI (2023)."
#| echo: false

import pandas as pd

# Select relevant columns
cols = ['country', 'gdp_per_capita', 'life_expectancy', 'unemployment_rate']
subset = df[cols].dropna()

# TOP 10 SUMMARY

top10_summary = {

    'Mean Unemployment rate (%)': [top10['unemployment_rate'].mean()]
}

# GLOBAL SUMMARY 
global_summary = {
    'Group': ['Global average (all countries)'],
    'Mean GDP per capita (US$)': [subset['gdp_per_capita'].mean()],
    'Mean Life expectancy (years)': [subset['life_expectancy'].mean()],
    'Mean Unemployment rate (%)': [subset['unemployment_rate'].mean()]
}

# Combine both summaries
comparison_df = pd.concat([
    pd.DataFrame(top10_summary),
    pd.DataFrame(global_summary)
]).reset_index(drop=True)

# Format and apply color gradients
styled_table = (
    comparison_df.style
    .format({
        'Mean GDP per capita (US$)': '{:,.2f}',
        'Mean Life expectancy (years)': '{:,.2f}',
        'Mean Unemployment rate (%)': '{:,.2f}'
    })
    .background_gradient(
        subset=['Mean GDP per capita (US$)', 'Mean Life expectancy (years)'],
        cmap='Greens'  # higher = greener
    )
    .background_gradient(
        subset=['Mean Unemployment rate (%)'],
        cmap='Reds'   # higher = redder 
    )
    .set_table_styles([
        {'selector': 'th', 'props': [('text-align', 'center'), ('background-color', '#f2f2f2')]},
        {'selector': 'td', 'props': [('text-align', 'center')]}
    ])
    .set_caption("Key indicators for top 10 GDP per capita countries compared to global averages.")
)

styled_table

```

According to global data from the World Bank [@worldbank2023], GDP per capita and life expectancy are strongly correlated, a trend also shown in Our World in Data [@owid_life_vs_gdp].
